name: Minted to Skinted: Cocktails for Every Budget

text.text: Minted to Skinted: London's Best Cocktail Bars

Cocktails are a fine thing, they make you feel fancy, grown up and maybe even a little powerful (we're aiming somewhere between 'Mad Men' and 'Sex and the City' realness). The thing is a night on the cocky Ts does burn through the funds like nothing else, especially if you're foolish enough to be doing rounds. 

So here are some options to help you manage your cocktail habit throughout the month - from bank balance ballin' to pre-payday pauperin'.
** MINTED **

When paying for the pleasure, you can expect every aspect to be luxurious - from the mighty comfortable seats, to the fine spirits and exquisite glassware, daaahling. You're also likely to be paying for table service in these ends so take that into account, nibble away at any free nuts and make your '2 years with this one' selfies count.

tip.text:
Ever felt like the cocktail bar you were in could have been the one, if it wasn't for the overly showy clientele? Tucked up beside Merchant House, The Brig only has space for two-to-four guests - that's you and whoever you choose to bring - no hen dos, suits or PDA couples in sight.

Once you've settled in this cosy spot, sip on a glass of bubbles while you decide on (1) what you'd like to drink; and (2). what you'd like to listen to - that's right you can pick the tunes as well. It's basically like an Uber but with drinks. And since you only have one hour to drink as many cocktails as your little heart desires, we'd recommend getting an Uber home too.

£50 per head, so drink up, kiddo.

text.text:
If you're feeling especially baller and need an entire bar to yourself, you'll be glad to hear The Brig only has space for 2-4 people. Once you've settled in this cosy spot, sip on a glass of bubbles while you decide on (1) what you'd like to drink; and (2) what you'd like to listen to - that's right you can pick the tunes as well. 

Cocktails: £50pp for an hour of unlimited cocktails

tip.text:
Having been voted the best bar in the world for four consecutive years by industry experts, it was only fair we gave this baby a mention. Luxury, opulence, comfort and style literally seep from this place - it's the tits. We’ve gotta take off our hats to the Head Bartender, Alex Kratena, who switches up the entire cocktail menu every year with an impressively creative theme. His most recent launch was the ‘Surrealism’ menu, where each cocktail subverts the notion of reality, everyday objects and the idea of a traditional ‘serve’.

We’d recommended going for a ‘You’re So Gangsta #feelinglikeaboss cocktail - not only does it look but tastes like a million bucks - Grey Goose shaken up with Yuzu, Lychee, Ginseng, Juniper and Rose.

text.text:
Having been voted the best bar in the world for four consecutive years by industry experts, you should really check this baby out - if only once. Luxury and style go hand-in-hand here - think expertly crafted cocktails with plenty of theatre. 

Cocktails: £17-19

tip.text: Step out of reality and into a glamorous, Art Deco world perfect for playing out illicit affairs and high-end dodgy dealings. This basement bar underneath Brasserie Zedel is a beautiful, French bar fitted out with dark wood, leather seating and a ridiculous but fabulous tiger print carpet. Cocktails are pricey at £14 but worth it for the added drama of the place. Go for a classic (Martini, Whiskey Sour, Daiquiri) or something a little more reflective of the bar like The French Aperitif made with gin, byrrh, lemon juice, orgeat, bitter lemon and cherry bitters.

text.text:
Art Deco is dialled all the way up at Bar Américain, from the Zedel team. Sit in amongst mirrors, dark wood and tiger print carpets; order a French Aperitif - made with gin, byrrh, lemon juice, orgeat, bitter lemon and cherry bitters - and live out your film noir fantasies.

Cocktails: £12-13.50

tip.text:
Remember that sexy menu at Peg + Patriot? Well we do. And so does Matt Whiley (aka The Talented Mr Fox) 'cause he put it together. He got a food waste shaped bee in his bonnet and decided to set up a cocktail bar that's all about reducing it. How? Using only sustainable ingredients, distilling, fermenting and brewing in an on-site 'lab' and waging war on straws.

You too can fight the good fight, in a more relaxed manner, by slurping on his seasonal cocktails. Think strawberry wine, lemon balm gin and whey, or the fresher carrot, hemp seed and liquorice. Soak it up with sourdough and homemade kohlrabi or pickled celeriac and truffle and you might as well be at a spa. Sort of.

text.text:
Matt Whiley got a food-waste-shaped bee in his bonnet and set up a cocktail bar that uses only sustainable ingredients, and ferments all sorts in his on-site 'lab'. When drinking at Scout you can expect to learn a little and taste a lot. 

Cocktails: £11-12

tip.text: The brains behind two of the city's best and most refined cocktail bars - Nightjar and Milk & Honey - have come together to bring Swift to Soho. Said concept involves an upstairs/ downstairs setup featuring a standing bar upstairs facilitating classy binge drinking - champagne, vermouth, oysters and cocktails are all served double time to cater to time-pressed Londoners. Downstairs the bar takes a more languid approach to drinking with 1930s interiors,  low lighting, a live pianist, a heck load of whiskeys and a few small plates including steak tartare with crostini, and Guinness Welsh rarebit.

text.text:
The brains behind two of the city's best and most refined cocktail bars - Nightjar and Milk & Honey - have come together to bring Swift to Soho. Upstairs facilitates classy binge drinking with champagne, vermouth, oysters and cocktails, while downstairs takes a more languid approach with whisky cocktails that are certainly worth the wait.

Cocktails: £10-12
** PLAYING IT SAFE **

These bars have kept the mixologists, quality ingredients and fine  workmanship but stripped away unnecessary pomp. In fact it's highly likely the cocktails will be more inventive, and the whole experience more friendly, whilst still feeling like a treat - perfect for impressing a date without breaking the bank.

tip.text:
You want downright barmy experimentation? Alright, you got it. How about a cocktail made with Chicken Salt, Sweetcorn Syrup and Chicken Skin? Or maybe a cheeky nightcap with Quinoa Beer, Eucalyptus Shrub and Cured Crocodile?

The Shrub & Shutter has brought its loopy take on drinking to Brixton, and its pretty darn popular. There's a menu of more traditional, high quality British dishes too which is constantly changing, but the cocktails are the crowd pleasers/shockers here. Come for date night drinks and the potential of a little reckless abandon.

text.text:
How about a cocktail made with chicken salt, sweetcorn syrup and chicken skin? The Shrub & Shutter has brought its experimental cocktails to Brixton with a menu of British bites to go alongside 'em. It's a kind of low-key fancy, first-date material bar. 

Cocktails: £9.50-12

tip.text:
You might be forgiven for thinking you were walking into a pub called the White Horse but in fact you're in an 80s New York cocktail bar. If you like sipping on curious but clever cocktails this one is for you. Previously White Lyan, Super Lyan has kept the booth seating and striper pole we know and love but revamped the ol' menu.

The clever clogs behind the bar, headed by cocktail guru Ryan Chetiyawardana, distill some of their own spirits, make their syrups and try and reuse as much as possible. They've got some waste citrus juice - they'll make a sorbet. A little leftover watermelon rind? A cucumber and watermelon agave it is. Now you know they're doing good you can sit back and enjoy your Dog's Nose Clover Club' - made with Chambord, botanical sherbet, Guinness and lemon. Aaah, pass the spiced nuts please.

text.text:
If you like sipping on curiously clever cocktails, this one is for you. Another waste conscious bar, headed up by cocktail guru Ryan Chetiyawardana, Super Lyan distill some of their own spirits, make their own syrups and bottle up all sorts of marvels.

Cocktails: £9.50

tip.text:
This cocktail bar has nabbed all the best bits of French culture to make something pretty darn sophistiqué. The decor and vibe is classy as hell: not a gimmick in sight, and plenty of grown up flavours with spirits like Calvados and Armagnac featuring heavily. Even the 'fun' choices are très chic: the piña colada with coconut sorbet and Moët & Chandon was a perfect dessert alternative. There's many a champagne cocktail (once you pop a bottle of Moët you as well pour it in everything right?) though we fell hard for the 'First Things First'. Whisky based with dry vermouth and a touch of fruitiness, we want them to bottle it so we can drink it forever more.

There's also a fine nibble to be had with charcuterie boards and some pongy French cheese platters (pongy in the best possible way). What with the friendly service, it's all pretty smart-casual-smart and we quite like it.

text.text:
Coupette has nabbed all the best bits of French culture to make something pretty darn sophistiqué - with plenty of grown up flavours; and spirits like Calvados and Armagnac featuring heavily. Order a 'First Things First' - a heavenly blend of whisky and dry vermouth with a touch of fruitiness.

Cocktails: £8-10

tip.text:
Tucked in between brighter, louder restaurants on Kingsland Road, Three Sheets is easy to walk right past. This dimly lit watering hole is short on space but makes up for it by oozing atmosphere with a white-marble bar and a single row of two-seater high tables, just begging to be the backdrop for a hot date or a moody, solitary cocktail.

Serving Alchemy coffee, light snacks, and a weekly rotating menu of inventive, seasonal cocktails, this inconspicuous neighbourhood bar can certainly hold its own in terms of quality. It's owned by two lovely Northern lads (catch them behind the bar, always ready to engage in pleasant chatter), one of whom gained his stripes working at Tony Conigliaro’s Drink Factory, where cocktails are developed for some of London's best bars. A little spot with a lot of love - we'll raise a well-mixed drink to that.

text.text:
This small, dimly lit watering hole on Kingsland Road is easy to walk right past but enter and you'll be surprised by the sultry atmosphere, white marble bar top and a rotating menu of inventive, seasonal cocktails (think an Old Fashioned made with oats, manuka leaf, lemon, and sweetened with organic maple syrup). 

Cocktails: from £9

tip.text:
All the silver linings here with strong drinks, low lights and good times. This cosy, quaint and intimate little spot is located right around the corner from Hackney Empire and features your perfect East Laandan cocktail list, including a monthly rejig of the classic old fashioned.

Once you've chosen your poison from the witty (if a little try hard) menu, prepare to be impressed. We like a sherry heavy menu so went for the 'Sherry Woo Woo'. We're fully on board with making sherry cool again. Maybe that should be our new slogan.

text.text:
This cloud offers all the silver linings with strong and original drinks, low lighting and a dash of pineapple wallpaper. We like a sherry-heavy menu so went for the 'Sherry Woo Woo' -We're bringing sherry back, boys.

Cocktails: £9-10
** SKINTED **

We're now getting to the underground den/railway arch end of the scale. You're paying for the cocktails here, not the leather menus or the art deco finishings. Cocktails are simple but still carefully though out and delicious, and nobody will ask you to keep it down.

tip.text: This underground cubby hole provides excellent seasonal cocktails, a small menu of tasty bites and some of the best quality sound this side of the Brandenburg Gate. Propping up the bar here reminds us of being in the kitchen at a house party - a particularly stylish one. It may be a squeeze, but you get the feeling you'll miss something truly great if you leave. It wouldn't be unusual to share a knowing smile with the DJ over some crisp electronic beats; or swap a joke with the bar staff while they cooly whip you up a blend of unknown spirits with genuinely inventive seasonal touches. This is a cocktail emporium of the most laid-back variety; a good time bar with exceedingly good taste.

text.text:
BTW's basement cubby hole administers ‘medicinal’ and 'additive-free' cocktails via a changing seasonal menu. We enjoyed a Salem Witch Reviver when we were in - made with white rum, coffee liqueur, maraska liqueur and maple candied apple. Let it also be known that there's a daily 'happy hour' from 6-8pm.

Cocktails: £8.50-13

tip.text:
The vibes are strong at this sunny little slice of Jamaican cool in the arches under Deptford rail station. It grew from one man’s dream to create a relaxed, inclusive bar that paid tribute to his own heritage and the neighbourhood’s Jamaican diaspora; now, local movers and shakers pack the place on a Saturday night, getting loose to R&B, soul, reggae, and the occasional live band.

But when patrons aren’t dutty wine-ing on the dance floor, they’re stuffing their gullets with a vegan take on Jamaican fare. Try goodies like braised aubergine with gungo rice 'n' peas or a smokey jackfruit burger that we’re still thinking about. Wash it all down with some choice bevvies, like the light ’n’ fresh Cucumber Cocktail.

text.text:
Bursting with Jamaican vibes in the arches under Deptford rail station, Buster Mantis offers a mighty relaxed, rum-heavy cocktail menu, some savoury saltfish fritters and a mix of R&B, soul, reggae, and the occasional live band... more than a few opportunities to dutty wine then. 

Cocktails: £7-8

tip.text:
This shape-shifting cafe-cum-tapas-bar-cum-cocktail-den dishes out a little taste of Spain from the morn to midnight nearly every day. The owners, Johnny and Liam, have a soft spot for España, and felt that the market lacked a laid-back place where they could go out. They put their minds together and out came Seven, a casual tapas bar with serious vibes.

We're huge fans of their ever-changing cocktail list, which always features one mainstay: the refreshing af ginger beer and basil mojito. As for the tapas, they're not messing about - it's that authentic Spanish fare, like jamon serrano (cured for sixteen months) and pimiento del padron with rock salt.

text.text:
Seven is a Brixton Market favourite, known for its reasonable cocktails and Spanish tapas plates. Cocktails are pretty simple, but they hit the spot alright. On a hot day you'll be wanting the refreshing af ginger beer and basil mojito.

Cocktails: £6-7.50

tip.text:
Tucked underneath Peckham Rye station, the cool kids of SE15 (and some trans-borough pilgrims) congregate at this stripped-back cocktail bar for vibezy evenings fuelled by their killer cocktail list. On most nights its arches are rammed with shrewd merrymakers getting sozzled on their cheap drinks and gorging on their banging pizzas.

The happy hour here is legendary: drop in any day between 6-7pm and bag two cocktails for £7 - everyone knows it's all about rollin' with one in each hand. When the sun's out, the action spills out back into their bustling courtyard space, where punters bask in the laid-back, no frills ambience.

text.text:
Bar Story and it's neighbour, Peckham Springs, are all about the reasonably-priced-cocktails-in-railway-arches life. Clientele is arty, drinks are simple, fruity and excellent value (especially between 6-7pm where you can double up your cocktail for an extra £2).

Cocktails: £6-8

tip.text:
Run by the super friendly Diddy herself, this is an all-day cafe/bar that's quickly become a local hub - the kind of place where you'll overhear a convo going on next to you and feel compelled to join in. They're not trying to do anything too fancy here, just provide a colourful, chilled spot to unwind, chat and feel at home, and we're big fans.

A short menu offers staple brunch bits, and if you’re after something stronger, there’s a reasonably priced cocktail list to check too (£5.50 Aperol spritzes... for real). London is short on continental-style places to get cocktails late without the formalities of a bar; this is just that laid-back ticket.

text.text:
Diddy isn't trying to do anything too fancy with her cafe-cum-bar; she simply wants provide a colourful, chilled spot to unwind, chat and feel at home. You could certainly do worse than an Amaretto sour for seven quid.

Cocktails: £5.50-7.50

tip.text:
Helgi’s is like being in the sixties - minus the racism and the sexism. A time warp in the middle of London Fields, transporting you back to the Summer of Luuuuvvvvvv. A better time, filled with free love, psychotropic drugs and hippie garms. A welcome break from the Tinder hook-ups, ket and bucket hats that plague our millennial generation.

The bar is intimate, and the smell of incense wafts in the air. A vinyl player blasts out tunes from the 60s, whilst wavy, psychedelic projections cover the walls. To properly enjoy the vibe, a cocktail is needed, of course. Try the Alabama Slammer, a mix of sloe gin, whisky, Galliano and Cointreau topped with orange juice. Some might say mixing that much alcohol is a bad idea, but this is the 60s honey, and mixing all substances is to be encouraged.

text.text:
If you're looking to get wavey on a budget whilst feeling a little psychedelic too, Helgi's is your spot. Try the Alabama Slammer, a mix of sloe gin, whisky, Galliano and Cointreau topped with orange juice; and enjoy London's dishevelled side. 

Cocktails: £4-6
